_exec_summary.SummaryText:
has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary.  Valero's program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Valero coordinates its emergency response program and response actions with the Galveston County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Texas City Refinery conducts emergency drills that involve the Texas City Industrial Mutual Aid System and the Texas City Fire Department.  The refinery has 24/7 communication capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations to provide a means of notifying the public of an incident as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Valero is continuously investigating and reviewing technology and/or applications that could possibly enhance its safety efforts.  These currently include:
 - Refinery Fire Water System Upgrade
 - Corporate Transition to Impact/Cut Resistant Work Gloves
 - Corporate Control of Hazardous Energy and Materials (CHEM) Assessment
 - Replacement of C8 extinguishing Foam With C6 Foam
 - Replacement of All Single Arm Ladder Swing Gates With Double Arm Swing Gates
 - HF Alkylation Main Fractionator Reboiler H-28 Burner Management Safety System Additions
 - HF Alkylation Installation of 4 Additional Elevated Remote Operated Fire Monitors 
 - HF Alkylation Installation of 6 Additional Surveillance Cameras
 - Corporat

n (ESD) Plan
- High Integrity Pressure Protective Systems (HIPPS)
Electronic Unit Entry and Personnel Accountability System
Camera monitoring in the Alky area
Release Mitigation
- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
- Deluge system for specific equipment
- Trained on-site emergency response organization
- Hand-held and wheeled cart fire extinguishers
- Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.)
Blast-resistant buildings and safe havens to help protect personnel and control systems

4 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In the last 5 years, the refinery has experienced one accidental release as defined by 40 CFR Part 68.42 that met the criteria to be defined as an RMP covered accident. The accidental release met the 40 CFR Part 68.42 definition because it resulted in significant onsite property damage.

The RMP covered incident occurred on 19th April, 2018 when a release, followed by a fire, occurred from the piping on the main fractionator tower in the HF Alkylation unit. No employees or contractors sustained a reportable injury as a result of the event. Emergency response by refinery personnel was immediate.  The Valero Texas City Refinery has conducted a formal incident investigation to identify and correct the identified cause(s) of the event. 

5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Valero maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program includes procedures for responding to a loss of containment, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans an accounting for personnel, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident management.  

Additionally, the Texas City refinery

eam develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until resolution.  The resolution of each finding is documented.  Most recent audit reports are retained.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Hazards in the processes are continually managed to ensure safe operations.  The existing safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances in the refinery are described below.

For toxic substances, Valero has reviewed and adopted recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices, industry guidelines and manufacturer's recommendations regarding safe storage and handling.  This includes personnel training as well as robust equipment designs.  For flammables, Valero has adopted several API, NFPA, insurance company, ASME, ANSI, and other codes and standards.

Uniform Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP-covered processes.  These prevention programs are designed and implemented to prevent potential accidental release scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.

Specialized Safety Features
Specialized Safety Features are features intended to help prevent, quickly detect and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:
Release Detection
- Hydrocarbon, hydrogen sulfide, and hydrofluoric acid detectors and alarms
Release Containment and Control
- Process relief valves that discharge to a Flare Gas Recovery and Flare Stacks to capture and/or incinerate
episodic releases
-Remote Valves for safe isolation of the process (manual or automated)
Automatic shutdown systems for specific process
Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases
Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
Total plant emergency shutdow

(3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; 
(4) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work); and 
(5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. 
These procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely at the refinery.  

Management of Change
Valero has a comprehensive system to manage change to the processes at the refinery.  Changes to process equipment, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, changes to the quantity of regulated substances in the process, and other process changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Reviews ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate a change.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are notified of the changes and, if necessary, trained on the changes.

Incident Investigation
Valero promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action for the prevention of the same or a similar incident.  Findings and recommendations are documented and are forwarded to refinery management for resolution.  

Compliance Audits
Valero periodically conducts audits to determine the implementation of the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  An audit t

mergency response plan requirements; and
(4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work. 

In addition, Valero evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process.  Valero personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.  

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
Valero conducts a PSSR on any new process or process modification that requires a change in process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides an additional check that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
Valero has practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment at the refinery.  The aspects of this program include: 
(1) training; 
(2) written procedures; 
(3) performing inspections and tests; 
(4) correcting identified equipment deficiencies; and 
(5) applying quality assurance measures. 
These activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the processes.  

Valero incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.  

Safe Work Practices
Valero has safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and safety.  Examples of these include:
(1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel;
(2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance;

tors and the public.

Valero strongly promotes employee involvement in safety issues through, for example, regularly scheduled safety meetings, tool box safety meetings, hazard communications, safety suggestions, incident reporting system, and special training programs such as emergency response training and first aid training.  Valero actively seeks employee involvement in the development and implementation of all accident prevention activities through the appropriate programs.  Accident prevention is discussed at the regularly scheduled safety meetings and/or during special training sessions, if necessary.  Employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors and to bring any questions, comments or suggestions forward for open discussion.

Process Safety Information
Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology and process equipment is essential to an effective accident prevention program, as well as completing and maintaining process hazard analysis of covered units.  The process safety information is readily available to all employees and used by refinery personnel, the process hazard analysis team, and persons in charge of updating the emergency response plan.  Valero maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operations.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration.  Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS).

Valero also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment at the refinery.  This information includes, but is not limited to, materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings, and electrical ra

tal of nineteen (19) RMP covered processes. Eighteen (18) processes are subject to Program 3 and one (1) process is eligible for Program 1 requirements per the U.S. EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program (RMP).

In the latest update of the RMP, evaluation of the processes and changes resulted in change of several Program 1 processes to Program 3. The inventories used for determining offsite consequences have also been updated since the 2016 submittal.

3 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Valero has implemented an accidental release prevention program.  In March of 2002, Valero's Texas City refinery was recognized as a Star Site in OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).  Star Site designation is OSHA's highest honor to recognize the nation's most effective industrial safety and health programs.  To date, only 15% of U.S. refineries have earned this distinction. One of the key success indicators that earned the Valero Texas City refinery Star Site designation is the plant's continually declining injury rates. For the last three years, the refinery's recordable employee injury rate has been well below the industry average.  The refinery's contractor recordable injury rate has also been better than industry standards.  The accidental release prevention program required for Program 3 processes is summarized as follows:

Employee Participation
Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the refinery's accident prevention program is a critical component of the overall objective to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of a flammable or toxic substance.  Employee involvement helps to ensure that all perspectives regarding accident prevention are considered for implementation.  Open communications are encouraged between supervisors and employees regarding all aspects of safety and health issues concerning employees, contrac

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Valero Energy Corporation (Valero) owns and operates the Texas City Refinery (Refinery). Valero has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety and protecting the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, including training of personnel and safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes at the refinery. Valero implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. Valero places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspection and regularly training responsible personnel. Should a release occur, the refinery's trained personnel will respond to control, contain, and mitigate the release.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, document the five-year accident history of the facility, and list planned changes to improve safety at the plant. The Risk Management Plan is also intended to ensure compliance with the regulations.

2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Valero Texas City Refinery operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products from crude oil, such as gasoline, diesel, petroleum coke, and streams for use as chemical feedstocks. The refinery is subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) - Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations. The refinery has a threshold quantity of several flammable substances and one toxic substance (hydrogen fluoride). Regulated flammable substances at the refinery include butane, isobutane, isopentane, propane, propylene, and flammable mixtures of various regulated flammable substances.
